trans-unit.source: How to use File storage from Java | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use File storage from Java | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the Azure file service to upload, download, list, and delete files.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the Azure file service to upload, download, list, and delete files.

trans-unit.source: Samples written in Java.
trans-unit.target: Samples written in Java.

trans-unit.source: How to use File Storage from Java
trans-unit.target: How to use File Storage from Java

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: In this guide you'll learn how to perform basic operations on the Microsoft Azure File storage service.
trans-unit.target: In this guide you'll learn how to perform basic operations on the Microsoft Azure File storage service.

trans-unit.source: Through samples written in Java you'll learn how to create shares and directories, upload, list, and delete files.
trans-unit.target: Through samples written in Java you'll learn how to create shares and directories, upload, list, and delete files.

trans-unit.source: If you are new to Microsoft Azure's File Storage service, going through the concepts in the sections that follow will be very helpful in understanding the samples.
trans-unit.target: If you are new to Microsoft Azure's File Storage service, going through the concepts in the sections that follow will be very helpful in understanding the samples.

trans-unit.source: Create a Java application
trans-unit.target: Create a Java application

trans-unit.source: To build the samples, you will need the Java Development Kit (JDK) and the [Azure Storage SDK for Java][].
trans-unit.target: To build the samples, you will need the Java Development Kit (JDK) and the [Azure Storage SDK for Java][].

trans-unit.source: You should also have created an Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: You should also have created an Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: Setup your application to use File storage
trans-unit.target: Setup your application to use File storage

trans-unit.source: To use the Azure storage APIs, add the following statement to the top of the Java file where you intend to access the storage service from.
trans-unit.target: To use the Azure storage APIs, add the following statement to the top of the Java file where you intend to access the storage service from.

trans-unit.source: Setup an Azure storage connection string
trans-unit.target: Setup an Azure storage connection string

trans-unit.source: To use File storage, you need to connect to your Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: To use File storage, you need to connect to your Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: The first step would be to configure a connection string which we'll use to connect to your storage account.
trans-unit.target: The first step would be to configure a connection string which we'll use to connect to your storage account.

trans-unit.source: Let's define a static variable to do that.
trans-unit.target: Let's define a static variable to do that.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Replace your_storage_account_name and your_storage_account_key with the actual values for your storage account.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Replace your_storage_account_name and your_storage_account_key with the actual values for your storage account.

trans-unit.source: Connecting to an Azure storage account
trans-unit.target: Connecting to an Azure storage account

trans-unit.source: To connect to your storage account, you need to use the **CloudStorageAccount** object, passing a connection string to its **parse** method.
trans-unit.target: To connect to your storage account, you need to use the **CloudStorageAccount** object, passing a connection string to its **parse** method.

trans-unit.source: **CloudStorageAccount.parse** throws an InvalidKeyException so you'll need to put it inside a try/catch block.
trans-unit.target: **CloudStorageAccount.parse** throws an InvalidKeyException so you'll need to put it inside a try/catch block.

trans-unit.source: How to: Create a Share
trans-unit.target: How to: Create a Share

trans-unit.source: All files and directories in File storage reside in a container called a **Share**.
trans-unit.target: All files and directories in File storage reside in a container called a **Share**.

trans-unit.source: Your storage account can have as much shares as your account capacity allows.
trans-unit.target: Your storage account can have as much shares as your account capacity allows.

trans-unit.source: To obtain access to a share and its contents, you need to use a File storage client.
trans-unit.target: To obtain access to a share and its contents, you need to use a File storage client.

trans-unit.source: Using the File storage client, you can then obtain a reference to a share.
trans-unit.target: Using the File storage client, you can then obtain a reference to a share.

trans-unit.source: To actually create the share, use the **createIfNotExists** method of the CloudFileShare object.
trans-unit.target: To actually create the share, use the **createIfNotExists** method of the CloudFileShare object.

trans-unit.source: At this point, **share** holds a reference to a share named **sampleshare**.
trans-unit.target: At this point, **share** holds a reference to a share named **sampleshare**.

trans-unit.source: How to: Upload a file
trans-unit.target: How to: Upload a file

trans-unit.source: An Azure File Storage Share contains at the very least, a root directory where files can reside.
trans-unit.target: An Azure File Storage Share contains at the very least, a root directory where files can reside.

trans-unit.source: In this section, you'll learn how to upload a file from local storage onto the root directory of a share.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you'll learn how to upload a file from local storage onto the root directory of a share.

trans-unit.source: The first step in uploading a file is to obtain a reference to the directory where it should reside.
trans-unit.target: The first step in uploading a file is to obtain a reference to the directory where it should reside.

trans-unit.source: You do this by calling the **getRootDirectoryReference** method of the share object.
trans-unit.target: You do this by calling the **getRootDirectoryReference** method of the share object.

trans-unit.source: Now that you have a reference to the root directory of the share, you can upload a file onto it using the following code.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have a reference to the root directory of the share, you can upload a file onto it using the following code.

trans-unit.source: How to: Create a Directory
trans-unit.target: How to: Create a Directory

trans-unit.source: You can also organize storage by putting files inside sub-directories instead of having all of them in the root directory.
trans-unit.target: You can also organize storage by putting files inside sub-directories instead of having all of them in the root directory.

trans-unit.source: The Azure file storage service allows you to create as much directories as your account will allow.
trans-unit.target: The Azure file storage service allows you to create as much directories as your account will allow.

trans-unit.source: The code below will create a sub-directory named **sampledir** under the root directory.
trans-unit.target: The code below will create a sub-directory named **sampledir** under the root directory.

trans-unit.source: How to: List files and directories in a share
trans-unit.target: How to: List files and directories in a share

trans-unit.source: Obtaining a list of files and directories within a share is easily done by calling **listFilesAndDirectories** on a CloudFileDirectory reference.
trans-unit.target: Obtaining a list of files and directories within a share is easily done by calling **listFilesAndDirectories** on a CloudFileDirectory reference.

trans-unit.source: The method returns a list of ListFileItem objects which you can iterate on.
trans-unit.target: The method returns a list of ListFileItem objects which you can iterate on.

trans-unit.source: As an example, the following code will list files and directories inside the root directory.
trans-unit.target: As an example, the following code will list files and directories inside the root directory.

trans-unit.source: How to: Download a file
trans-unit.target: How to: Download a file

trans-unit.source: One of the more frequent operations you will perform against file storage is to download files.
trans-unit.target: One of the more frequent operations you will perform against file storage is to download files.

trans-unit.source: In the following example, the code downloads SampleFile.txt and displays its contents.
trans-unit.target: In the following example, the code downloads SampleFile.txt and displays its contents.

trans-unit.source: How to: Delete a file
trans-unit.target: How to: Delete a file

trans-unit.source: Another common file storage operation is file deletion.
trans-unit.target: Another common file storage operation is file deletion.

trans-unit.source: The following code deletes a file named SampleFile.txt stored inside a directory named **sampledir**.
trans-unit.target: The following code deletes a file named SampleFile.txt stored inside a directory named **sampledir**.

trans-unit.source: How to: Delete a directory
trans-unit.target: How to: Delete a directory

trans-unit.source: Deleting a directory is a fairly simple task, although it should be noted that you cannot delete a directory that still contains files or other directories.
trans-unit.target: Deleting a directory is a fairly simple task, although it should be noted that you cannot delete a directory that still contains files or other directories.

trans-unit.source: How to: Delete a Share
trans-unit.target: How to: Delete a Share

trans-unit.source: Deleting a share is done by calling the **deleteIfExists** method on a CloudFileShare object.
trans-unit.target: Deleting a share is done by calling the **deleteIfExists** method on a CloudFileShare object.
